context.speaker: Bernard Nash
context.text: Texas v. New Jersey resolved that the State of the issuer... because Sun Oil was the issuer, had the authority... the equitable superiority of the right to escheat.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Well, it did also reject the contacts rule, because there'd be several States with contacts.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: It said that cannot be the sole rule.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: That's what Justice Black said.

context.speaker: Bernard Nash
context.text: That is correct, Justice Stevens.

context.speaker: Bernard Nash
context.text: The Federal money order statute, which was adopted by the Congress to govern escheat priority among the States, and not State laws developed for unrelated purposes, provides in our opinion far better guidance than State debtor-creditor law.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court in No. 111 original, Delaware against New York will be announced by Justice Thomas.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: This, in a state dispute, is before the Court under our original jurisdiction.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: At issue are unclaimed securities distributions held by intermediaries in their own names on behalf of beneficial owners cannot be identified or located.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: We also sustain Delaware's exception to the Master's proposal to award the right to escheat to the State in which the debtor has its principal executive offices rather than to the State in which the debtor is incorporated.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Finally, we reject New York's claim to a right to escheat based on statistical evidence that most of the relevant creditors are brokers with New York addresses.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: A State wishing to claim the right to escheat must prove transaction by transaction that a particular creditor had a last known address within that State.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Justice White has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens have joined.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: We also sustain Delaware's exception to the Master's proposal to award the right to escheat to the State in which the debtor has its principal executive offices rather than to the State in which the debtor is incorporated.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Finally, we reject New York's claim to a right to escheat based on statistical evidence that most of the relevant creditors are brokers with New York addresses.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: A State wishing to claim the right to escheat must prove transaction by transaction that a particular creditor had a last known address within that State.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Justice White has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens have joined.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: We also sustain Delaware's exception to the Master's proposal to award the right to escheat to the State in which the debtor has its principal executive offices rather than to the State in which the debtor is incorporated.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Finally, we reject New York's claim to a right to escheat based on statistical evidence that most of the relevant creditors are brokers with New York addresses.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: A State wishing to claim the right to escheat must prove transaction by transaction that a particular creditor had a last known address within that State.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, it may be... Mr. Starr, if I may interrupt you.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: It may be very similar, but there is a crucial constitutional difference depending on whether there are six pieces which are obscene and 600,000 which are merely erotic.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And it seems to me that your argument rests upon the identification of what is assumed and probably correctly assumed to be simply erotic adult material with the six which were shown to be obscene.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And that's your way of sort of getting out of the analogy that Justice Stevens is suggesting, and I don't see how that's a legitimate basis.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I don't see how we can assume the identity of eroticism with obscenity.

context.speaker: Kenneth W. Starr
context.text: --I don't think you have to make that assumption.

context.speaker: Kenneth W. Starr
context.text: There's no discussion or suggestion by Mr. Alexander that he alone has been singled out for prosecution.

context.speaker: Kenneth W. Starr
context.text: No.

context.speaker: Kenneth W. Starr
context.text: As long as the Government is proceeding with obscenity as the predicate, it is abiding by Congress' intent and it is not making content based distinctions.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Suppose it brought no other RICO... that's what I understood Justice Souter's questions to be.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The only RICO prosecution that the Government ever brings are obscenity prosecutions of this sort.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You wouldn't... you think that would be a basis to suspect that the Government is... has some antagonism towards the speech?

context.speaker: M. Margaret McKeown
context.text: In any event, there would be qualified immunity in that case, and it may well be that the decision, albeit not an adjudicative one, would not be subject to suit because there was qualified immunity.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, what would be... is there any potential judicial liability simply by virtue of the fact that the reporter may be held liable?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Are we talking about a respondeat superior here?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Because I would suppose... for example, in Justice Kennedy's case, I mean he's posing an example in which the judge's decision is a decision which is made on the administrative rather than the adjudicative side of the dichotomy in his duties, so that if the... if the reporter is negligent and the judge was negligent in keeping the reporter on, I assume there's going to be... could there be respondeat superior negligence here?

context.speaker: M. Margaret McKeown
context.text: If it's determined that the judge's conduct was adjudicative in nature, then there would be absolute immunity and you would not reach the respondeat superior.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, if it wasn't.

context.speaker: M. Margaret McKeown
context.text: --Federal law, excuse me.
Uh-hum.

context.speaker: M. Margaret McKeown
context.text: Federal law and pursuant to Federal statute and pursuant to the authority of the Federal court.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I'm not sure I understood your answer to Justice Stevens' question with respect to the State law contract action.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Did the... did the court below purport... did any Federal court below purport to... no, let me strike that.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Did the court of appeals purport to hold that there was absolute immunity with respect to the State contract action, or did the court of appeals, in effect, simply leave that to be adjudicated as a matter of State law if the claim was brought... was refiled as a State law claim?

context.speaker: M. Margaret McKeown
context.text: The concern is that given the court reporter obviously having some association with the judicial process, that there may be some reluctance to go that far.

context.speaker: M. Margaret McKeown
context.text: Our position, of course, ideally would be that she has no immunity because everything she does is totally ministerial and nonjudicial.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Yes, but one could disagree with you on that position so far as any claim based on Federal law against her, and perhaps any claim based... based on a cognate State law.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But a simple contract claim, hypothesized by Justice Stevens, where the defendant claims that he overpaid $200 for a transcript, it strikes me that whether the Federal law ought to impose on the State law system in immunity is quite debatable.

context.speaker: M. Margaret McKeown
context.text: I would agree with that.

context.speaker: M. Margaret McKeown
context.text: And assuming, of course, no particular State statute, were this to go back to the State court, we would argue no immunity with respect, certainly, to the contract action.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: If we took the trial court at face value would it still satisfy your view of the utter disregard?

context.speaker: Lynn E. Thomas
context.text: --I believe it would, Your Honor, although I would acknowledge that there are ambiguities in the trial court's description of the case and it is not as complete as we would have liked to see it.

context.speaker: Lynn E. Thomas
context.text: That of course is not the end of the line in our judicial sentencing system because the state supreme court conducts a full course of independent review of all death sentences.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Mr. Thomas, may I just go back to your answer to Justice Stevens' last question, because I'm not sure why it would, why this particular sentence would be consistent with your criterion.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: As I understand what you said a moment ago a murder would not qualify as manifesting utter disregard if it was committed with any kind of emotional provocation.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: There is certainly evidence of that, and that seems to be what the trial judge found.

context.speaker: Lynn E. Thomas
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Lynn E. Thomas
context.text: The trial judge's finding, or at least his statement that the murder was committed in an excessive violent rage and that the victim initially provoked the attack is very troublesome because it's not entirely consistent with the evidence.

context.speaker: Lynn E. Thomas
context.text: The evidence really was that Creech arranged for the attack--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: With respect, though, I think Justice Stevens' question was if we take the trial judge's finding on its face is this particular sentence consistent with your criterion.

context.speaker: Lynn E. Thomas
context.text: --Oh, I'm sorry.

context.speaker: Lynn E. Thomas
context.text: I misunderstood your question.

context.speaker: Lynn E. Thomas
context.text: I misunderstood your question.

context.speaker: Lynn E. Thomas
context.text: Yes, it is, but for a little different reason.

context.speaker: Lynn E. Thomas
context.text: The trial judge's findings at face value are ambiguous but they do contain findings that Creech had indicated he intended to keep on killing people, that he was remorseless and calculating, language essentially--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But the criterion is whether, as I understand it, is whether by the murder, which I assume, as Justice Kennedy was suggesting a moment ago, it means this murder or circumstances surrounding its commission, the defendant exhibits utter disregard.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: So I don't see how you can get beyond the record and say well, there are other, of this case, for the application of your standard.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And hence I don't see how you can in effect get around the trial judge's finding by looking to circumstances having nothing to do with this killing.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the court in No. 91-1160, Arave against Creech will be announced by Justice O'Connor.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: This case comes to us on writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals by the Ninth Circuit.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Respondent Thomas Creech entered a plea of guilty to first degree murder for the 1981 beating death of a fellow prison inmate.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: It describes the defendant's state of mind which is a fact that can be inferred from the surrounding circumstances.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: The Osborn construction also genuinely narrows the class of defendants eligible for the death penalty because the class of murders eligible to receive capital punishment in Idaho is large and a sentencer reasonably could find that not all are cold-blooded.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: We do not reach respondent's alternative argument that the utter disregard circumstance although constitutional, cannot be constitutionally applied to him, because under another holding of the Court of Appeals which is not before us today, the respondent is entitled to a new sentencing hearing.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Justice Blackmun has filed a dissenting opinion which Justice Stevens has joined.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor

context.text: We do not reach respondent's alternative argument that the utter disregard circumstance although constitutional, cannot be constitutionally applied to him, because under another holding of the Court of Appeals which is not before us today, the respondent is entitled to a new sentencing hearing.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Justice Blackmun has filed a dissenting opinion which Justice Stevens has joined.

context.speaker: Miguel A. Estrada
context.text: What we do have here is a statute that really doesn't need the criminal law other than to state a... other than to set a standard of conduct and, taking that as the standard of conduct, then says if your property has been used or is intended to be used for this purpose, then we will make sure that that harm doesn't come to pass by placing the property in the hands of someone who can give surety to society as a whole that these harms won't happen.

context.speaker: Miguel A. Estrada
context.text: And I think that's a very different type of forfeiture than the forfeiture that you have in mind, Justice Kennedy.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: May I ask you a question, Mr. Estrada?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Your discussion of two kinds of innocence and the different... your colloquy with Justice Kennedy brings this to mind.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: In the Dobbins Distillery case that you describe, the landlord knew that the property is going to be used for a distillery and perhaps had a higher duty to be sure they kept the records properly and so forth.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: But you say you would apply the same standard in a case like that as if just an ordinary landlord rented a flat somewhere to a party and had no reason to believe it was to be used for anything but a residence, and it turned out that the tenant dealt in drugs in the flat without any knowledge of the landlord.

context.speaker: Kevin M. Gillis
context.text: The--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I have a problem that's a slightly... it's a threshold problem on this same section while you're on it.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy

context.speaker: Kevin M. Gillis
context.text: --Well--

context.text: Why isn't it an injury?

context.speaker: Kevin M. Gillis
context.text: Secondly, Congress repeatedly in the legislative history mentions the problem that the disability from occupational diseases do not become manifest until oftentimes long after the injurious exposure occurs.

context.speaker: Kevin M. Gillis
context.text: Hearing loss is that type of disease.

context.speaker: Kevin M. Gillis
context.text: It doesn't become manifest until the worker happens to have his hearing tested, and that could be either before or after retirement.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, just as a practical matter, you know, if I'm exposed to something that causes me to lose my hearing and I find I used to be able to hear Justice Blackmun quite well when he whispered to me, but now I can't hear him at all, I don't need a hearing test to tell me that I've lost my hearing, do I?

context.speaker: Kevin M. Gillis
context.text: Well, you may feel subjectively that you've lost your hearing, but you may not have what a hearing test would show is an AMA percentage of hearing impairment.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, so you say the only way that something... a disease or injury can manifest itself is if there's some medical test that is performed to show it?

context.text: Well, what if I break my arm.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: That manifests itself rather dramatically, doesn't it, without necessarily going to a hospital and having an X-ray?

context.speaker: Kevin M. Gillis
context.text: I agree with that, but... and you would know your disability if you couldn't work, but here we're dealing with injuries as opposed to an occupational disease that evolves over time, and again I think that the date of manifestation and hearing loss is when the hearing is tested and an AMA disability can be determined.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You acknowledged in response to her question that the hearing loss occurs immediately at the time of employment when the... and is it not also true, or is it conceded that it does not get any worse?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: If you lost 15 percent, you've lost 15 percent, and it stays 15 percent.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: They were cruel in the way they did it and there were some disposal problems and certain other specific problems that they found.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: He also found, as I remember it, there's a lot of varieties of this religion.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Some have more of some customs and some have slightly different customs.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Supposing there was one branch of the religion that required as a part of the ceremony that it be conducted in a slaughterhouse as Justice Kennedy suggests, that it dispose of the remains in a lawful manner, and that it had none of the side effects that trouble you, and very properly.

context.text: But you have a religion that does sacrifice animals.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Now, that religion would be prohibited by your ordinance even if none of the side effects occurred, or were permitted to occur by the religion, is that not correct?

context.speaker: Richard G. Garrett
context.text: --Certainly, but they were ineffective.

context.speaker: Richard G. Garrett
context.text: They were obviously not accomplishing the purpose for which they were enacted, because it's very difficult to police a situation where people go out at night time or early in the morning with whole animals and leave them in parks, leave them under palm trees as it's dictated under the religious tenets, leave them at railroad crossings, leave them at the steps of courthouses in some instances... all of these dispersal of animal problems are problems that are in the record, and they are not simply a single goat.

context.speaker: Richard G. Garrett

City of Cincinnati v. Discovery Network,.case_name: City of Cincinnati v. Discovery Network, Inc.

context.speaker: Marc D. Mezibov
context.text: If here, for example, the problem with our publications is that it's commercial speech, then the city ought to... and I'm not suggesting this is what they ought to do, but to be fair they should ban all commercial speech, that contained in our publications and that which falls out of the daily newspapers on a daily basis.

context.speaker: Marc D. Mezibov
context.text: They've not chosen to do that, nor have they chosen... what they have chosen to do is make a distinction based on content, which does not meet the city's real needs.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Mr. Mezibov, I guess I don't understand your position, then.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I had thought from your briefs that your answer to Justice O'Connor's question would have been that you do not acknowledge... you do not acknowledge that commercial speech is not fully protected speech in the same sense that all speech is... I mean, in one sense no speech is fully protected speech, because it can't be given everywhere.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: There are restrictions that can be placed as to time, place, and manner.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I thought that's what your brief said, that commercial speech is speech, and it's entitled to constitutional protections.

City of Cincinnati v. Discovery Network,.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
City of Cincinnati v. Discovery Network,.case_name: City of Cincinnati v. Discovery Network, Inc.
City of Cincinnati v. Discovery Network,.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MARCH 24, 1993

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court in No. 91-1200, Cincinnati versus Discovery Network will be announced by Justice Stevens.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Respondent, Discovery Network, provides adult educational, recreational, and social programs in the Cincinnati area.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: It distributes a free magazine consisting primarily of promotional materials pertaining to its courses.

City of Cincinnati v. Discovery Network,.speaker: Justice Stevens
City of Cincinnati v. Discovery Network,.case_name: City of Cincinnati v. Discovery Network, Inc.
City of Cincinnati v. Discovery Network,.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MARCH 24, 1993

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The City's argument is based on the premise that commercial speech has only a low value and therefore commercial speech can always be subject to discriminatory treatment.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: In our view, however, the City attaches more importance to the distinction between commercial and non commercial speech than our cases warrant and seriously underestimates the value of commercial speech.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: In the absence of some basis for distinguishing between newspapers and commercial handbills that is relevant to the City's asserted intereset in safety in esthetics we are unwilling to recognize Cincinnati's bare assertion that the low value of commercial speech a sufficient justification for its selective and categorically ban on newsracks dispensing commercial handbills.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Justice Blackmun has filed the concurring opinion; the Chief Justice has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justice White and Justice Thomas have joined.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Are you really saying in my, the case I give to you, there is no right answer?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The fact finder can do just what he wants?

context.speaker: Kent L. Jones
context.text: Well, a priori I don't think there is necessarily a correct answer, although I--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Is the problem that you have in answering Justice Stevens' question the concession that I believe you made in your brief that there is always a principal place of business?

context.speaker: Kent L. Jones
context.text: --Well, that was the second answer I was going to give Justice Stevens, which is that this is not a statute in which the Government has to establish where the principal place of business is.

context.speaker: Kent L. Jones
context.text: This is a statute where the taxpayer has to establish that his home is his principal place of business.

context.text: Is the problem that you have in answering Justice Stevens' question the concession that I believe you made in your brief that there is always a principal place of business?

context.speaker: Kent L. Jones
context.text: --Well, that was the second answer I was going to give Justice Stevens, which is that this is not a statute in which the Government has to establish where the principal place of business is.

context.speaker: Kent L. Jones
context.text: This is a statute where the taxpayer has to establish that his home is his principal place of business.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, do you concede that there is always a principal place of business or do you argue that in some cases, say in Justice Stevens' hypothetical or a traveling salesman who just goes to 100 different places, that there is no principal place of business at all?

context.speaker: Kent L. Jones
context.text: Taking the word most important to its logical extreme you would think that in almost every case a fact finder could find a location that was most important.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy

context.speaker: David M. Sokolow

context.speaker: David M. Sokolow

context.speaker: David M. Sokolow

context.speaker: Kent L. Jones
context.text: We don't... one of the reasons I haven't emphasized it is because it doesn't seem that in good faith we can rely on a 12-year-old proposed regulation.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Well, and also the definition of principal place of business in the regulation is a little bit different from your position with regard to the statutory language, I think.

context.speaker: Kent L. Jones
context.text: It gives a little bit more emphasis to the place where income is generated.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens

context.speaker: Kent L. Jones
context.text: I think that there's room under the statute to agree with exactly what the regulation says, but I don't think that the regulation, by emphasizing slightly more where the income is generated, really adds that much to the fundamental inquiry of where is the most important place in the business.

context.speaker: Kent L. Jones
context.text: That's going to, different industries are going to have different reactions to where, is it important where they sell the goods or where they make them.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court No 91-998, Commission of internal revenue versus Soliman will be on announce by Justice Kennedy.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: This case requires us to consider the circumstances in which a taxpayer may claim a deduction on his federal income tax return for the expense of an office, that is located within the taxpayer's personal residence.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The case involves a medical doctor, who sought a deduction for a home office and the respondent, a doctor Solimon is an anesthesiologist.

Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Soli.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Soli.case_name: Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Soliman
Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Soli.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JANUARY 12, 1993

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: 10-15 hours per weeks spent in the home office measured against the 30-35 hours per week at the three hospitals are insufficient to render the home office the principal place of business in light of the circumstances of this case.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: That the office may have been essential is not controlling.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Hence, the taxpayer was not entitled the deduction for home expenses.

context.speaker: Dennis R. Murphy
context.text: The formula says that you simply give money.

context.speaker: Dennis R. Murphy
context.text: We don't have any nexus between how much money you gave and how much the liability is, and the more you give the more you owe, so in our case if we had just paid enough to fund our credits, the withdrawal liability would have been approximately $55,000, but they don't even try and make a relationship.

context.speaker: Dennis R. Murphy
context.text: It doesn't address it.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: As Justice Souter says, ordinarily the more you pay the more you do expose the... the more your operation does expose the fund to greater liability.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: As a general rule that's true, isn't it?

context.speaker: Dennis R. Murphy
context.text: I don't think so.

context.speaker: Robert H. Klonoff
context.text: Not inconsistent with the statute.

context.speaker: Robert H. Klonoff
context.text: We read the statute as allowing the serviceman, if title is transferred and there's a period of redemption, to take the title back.

context.speaker: Robert H. Klonoff
context.text: I suppose what could be done, since it talks about any period of redemption provided by law, is, I suppose, to not have any redemption period in this situation.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: No, but I just wanted to make sure that I understood what you were saying to Justice Scalia, and I thought the theory that you were espousing was that because the period of service is not included... cannot be included in computing the redemption period, that the redemption period never runs.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Because it never runs, Maine, or the town, whatever it is, never acquires the authority to give any title at all.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Isn't that your theory?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court in No. 91-1353, Conroy against Aniskoff will be announced by Justice Stevens.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: This case comes to us from the Supreme Court of Maine, it involves the question of construing the Soldiers' and Sailors' Civil Relief Act, and the question is whether a service man who fail to pay his taxes and has his property sold foreclosure was entitled to benefit of the Act which would enable him to postponed the period of redemption throughout his period of service.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The Maine Supreme Court in a divided opinion held that he was not entitled to the benefit of the statute because he could not prove that the service had caused him any prejudice with regard to his ability to pay his taxes, and felt that a literal reading on the statute which provide for the tolling of the redemption period was absurd and illogical.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The Maine Supreme Court in a divided opinion held that he was not entitled to the benefit of the statute because he could not prove that the service had caused him any prejudice with regard to his ability to pay his taxes, and felt that a literal reading on the statute which provide for the tolling of the redemption period was absurd and illogical.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: We granted certiorari to resolve a conflict and we reverse the judgment of the Supreme Judicial Court of Maine and hold that the statute basically means what it says.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: We reject the argument that the petitioner advances largely on the basis of legislative history and fairness and apply a literal construction of the Act.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Justice Scalia has filed an opinion concurring in the judgment.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court in No. 91-6194, Crosby against the United States will be announced by Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: This case comes to us from the Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The petitioner Crosby failed to appear at the beginning of his federal criminal trial.

context.speaker: Howard J. Trienens
context.text: That's what Congress did, and that's the way it works.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The problem--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --Go on.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I'm just pressing Justice Kennedy's point.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I think it is an important point because although it's time past and it's not involved in this case, it does bear upon whether your interpretation of when the preemption occurs is a reasonable one.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Your interpretation leaves a time period, namely the period after the promulgation of that regulation imposing upon the States the obligation to make that decision of what kind of mechanism you use and the point at which the State actually issues such a decision with respect to each crossing.

context.speaker: Howard J. Trienens
context.text: The plaintiff says under Georgia law, the railroad is responsible.

context.speaker: Howard J. Trienens
context.text: The Secretary has issued regulations saying that the States are exclusively responsible.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Mr. Trienens, why don't... why isn't a better explanation of what you're arguing for that this is conflict preemption?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I have the same trouble that Justice Souter does, squeezing this within the terms regulation, order, or standard relating to railroad safety.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I mean, there's no standard contained in that regulation.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It just allocates the responsibility for issuing the standard.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: That can't be by adjudication in your view.

context.speaker: Howard J. Trienens
context.text: --No.

context.speaker: Howard J. Trienens
context.text: It has got to be a State that has got to get it out.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I guess I have a problem that goes one step beyond Justice Stevens', and again it's a textual problem.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The regulation on speed... it was at 213.9... speaks simply in terms of the maximum allowable speed which again, by its terms, seems to imply to me that there may be some source of authority that could appropriately set a speed as appropriate, but less than that which is allowable, which again implies that there is some State authority left to do this.

context.speaker: Howard J. Trienens
context.text: Well, we don't agree that there's any such implication, and one of the reasons is that the Secretary of Transportation has a number of motives, one of which is to get the trains through.

context.speaker: Tambra P. Colston
context.text: But, Your Honor--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It's a safety factor too, is it not?

context.speaker: Tambra P. Colston
context.text: --Yes, it is.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I mean, not everybody is as patient as Justice Stevens and would sit there if it was a slow--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: Tambra P. Colston
context.text: Absolutely, Your Honor, and it is a safety factor.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy

context.text: The more important safeguard is that a court is entitled to direct a verdict, or in the words of the new Federal rules to direct a judgment, and likewise to grant summary judgment, if it concludes that even though there may be a scintilla of evidence supporting the petitioners' position, it is overwhelmingly refuted by the contrary evidence such that no reasonable juror could conclude on this body of evidence that the point for which the expert is contesting is true.

context.speaker: J. Gregory Clare

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia

context.speaker: Peter W. Sipkins
context.text: In addition there were no true concerns for sovereignty at the time that the amendment, that the Article III of the Constitution was enacted since after all of the Article III headings three of them specifically mention states themselves, six of them do not mention the states but nevertheless do not expressly exclude states from Federal jurisdiction.

context.speaker: Peter W. Sipkins
context.text: The Eleventh Amendment arose after Chisolm v. Georgia clearly as a result of concern for the colonies, then states, that they were fiscally strapped and they did not want to have after the war the state treasuries invaded by the Federal jurists.

context.speaker: Peter W. Sipkins
context.text: This was not a situation where the framers of the amendment stated clearly and unequivocally that there should be no ability of the Federal courts to bring the states before the bar.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, to what extent, Mr. Sipkins, can we look behind the language of the amendment which, as Justice Souter pointed out, speaks in terms of suits?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: You say you can look back to earlier drafts?

context.speaker: Peter W. Sipkins
context.text: Mr. Chief Justice, what I am suggesting is that you can look back to earlier drafts to determine whether the framers clearly intended to preclude suits against sovereigns, and that it was clear that they did not in the earlier drafts because the language was far more clear in the earlier drafts with respect to what they intended.

context.text: Going back to Justice Scalia's question, why don't you draw a distinction between a duty to warn about what a third party might do, on the one hand, and a duty to warn about what the person giving the warning might do?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I thought you were basing your argument in this case on the fact that we simply do not... tort law generally does not recognize a duty to warn of one's own malevolence, but tort law does recognize a duty to warn of risks that are beyond the control of the person giving the warning.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And yet, you don't seem to accept that distinction.

context.speaker: Everett C. Johnson, Jr.
context.text: And we agree fully that the purpose of the activity, whether sovereign or commercial, is utterly irrelevant.

context.speaker: Everett C. Johnson, Jr.
context.text: We looked at the nature of the activity itself.

context.speaker: Everett C. Johnson, Jr.
context.text: Even if the sovereign state acted with a commercial purpose, which of course Saudi Arabia denies in this case, but even if that were to be true, the activity would become no more inherently commercial in its nature.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, suppose in Justice Stevens' hypothetical of the security guards beating up the employee, they did it in order to punish the employee for transgressions on the job and to teach other employees not to do that in the future.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Is that not a commercial activity?

context.speaker: Everett C. Johnson, Jr.
context.text: Your Honor, I think your hypothetical aptly defines their motivation, their purpose, but I think what the Court said in Weltover is that that's irrelevant, and we look at the nature of the conduct itself, not what motivates the conduct to determine whether the activity is commercial.

context.speaker: Everett C. Johnson, Jr.
context.text: Your Honor, I think your hypothetical aptly defines their motivation, their purpose, but I think what the Court said in Weltover is that that's irrelevant, and we look at the nature of the conduct itself, not what motivates the conduct to determine whether the activity is commercial.

context.speaker: Everett C. Johnson, Jr.
context.text: To be sure, that's a difficult inquiry.

context.speaker: Everett C. Johnson, Jr.
context.text: I think the Court recognized that in Weltover.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I take it your criterion in answering Justice Kennedy's question is that what's commercial or not depends on what is commercial in the United States.

context.speaker: Everett C. Johnson, Jr.
context.text: That's correct, Justice Souter.

context.speaker: Everett C. Johnson, Jr.
context.text: That is our view.

context.speaker: Paul S. Stevens
context.text: These are the allegations that define the jurisdictional issue with respect to both the commercial nature of the activities and the substantial contact with the United States.

context.speaker: Paul S. Stevens
context.text: Now, in our view it doesn't make any difference that this particular employer chose to retaliate against its employee by detention and torture rather than by firing him and sending him home.

context.speaker: Paul S. Stevens
context.text: Certainly if the hospital had breached the employment contract with Mr. Nelson, that act would be commercial, and beating and torture can't be less commercial just because they're so much more extreme.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Stevens, you said earlier I think in response to a question from Justice Scalia that you thought the act divided conduct into governmental and commercial.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Is that correct?

context.speaker: Paul S. Stevens
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court in No. 91-522, Saudi Arabia versus Nelson will be announced by Justice Souter.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: This case comes to us on writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The respondents, a married couple named Nelson, filed this action for damages for personal injury against the petitioner's the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia Saudi hospital and the hospital's corporate purchasing agent.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: In an opinion filed today with the Clerk of the Court, we reverse the judgment of the Eleventh Circuit and hold that the Act does not confer jurisdiction over the Nelsons' suit.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Under the restrictive theory of Foreign Sovereign Immunity, which the Act codifies the Saudi Government's alleged detention and torture of Nelson do not qualify as commercial activities, and to allow that Nelsons' to proceed alternatively on a failure of warn theory with effectively toward the Act manifest purpose.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The case is reduced something less than complete unanimity.

context.speaker: William K. Kelley
context.text: --At that point--

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: --because you don't... you have no idea whether you're going to win or lose.

context.speaker: William K. Kelley
context.text: --At that point, we would acknowledge he cannot state that he is for certain a prevailing party.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: So, you do have to sort of, as Justice Scalia said, make mishmash out of this provision.

context.speaker: William K. Kelley
context.text: Well, we would suggest that it is not so much of a mishmash.

context.speaker: William K. Kelley
context.text: The only difficulty here is the--

context.speaker: William K. Kelley
context.text: It does make sense of the whole scheme.

context.speaker: William K. Kelley
context.text: But I would hasten to add that it is fully consistent with the statute and very workable to say that you can file a fee application when the proceedings on remand begin or... excuse me... after you get your remand, and you can state at that time you've done everything you can to be a prevailing party, and it is a small matter to come back to court after the proceedings on remand are finished.

context.speaker: William K. Kelley
context.text: If there are no further questions--

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: --Well, the... Justice Scalia's suggestion, which is very attractive since it's so simple, but it also would involve deciding here, which has never been decided here before--

context.speaker: William K. Kelley
context.text: --That's exactly right.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: --that you're not entitled to fees on remand.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Why... how could he appeal it.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That's absolutely right.

context.speaker: Randall J. Fuller
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: So, maybe at that juncture, as Justice Scalia has suggested, maybe at that point, the claimant is entitled to seek EAJA fees for the court proceeding that resulted in a sentence four remand order.

context.speaker: Randall J. Fuller
context.text: And that may, in fact, be the case, as was discussed previously by counsel.

context.speaker: Randall J. Fuller
context.text: The Court has not held--

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: It means the Government may end up paying more in fees because it will be paying fees even though the claimant might lose ultimately.

context.speaker: Randall J. Fuller
context.text: That's possible, but there would not be the Hudson fees added on later.

context.speaker: Randall J. Fuller
context.text: So, it may work out to be essentially a wash.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well, I would think you would embrace Justice Scalia's proposal if you assume that you're not going to get fees for your work after remand.

context.speaker: Randall J. Fuller
context.text: And as we have... as I have indicated, Justice White, we would not be opposed to such a ruling.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Yes, and if... I would think you would just like to be able to collect fees immediately and... because your fee won't depend on whether or not you win below, but you will still want to win below for your... on behalf of your client.

context.speaker: Robinson O. Everett
context.text: That we think is the fatal flaw.

context.speaker: Robinson O. Everett
context.text: We think that perhaps the issue of compactness could have been raised differently in that case and there might have been some constitutional issues before you.

context.speaker: Robinson O. Everett
context.text: But what we are saying is that even in search of diversity in the Congress, the legislature of North Carolina and the Attorney General can go only so far, but they cannot go as far as they went in this particular instance.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, that brings us back to the point Justice Stevens was beginning to discuss with you.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Isn't a State free to reject the idea of compactness if it chooses?

context.speaker: Robinson O. Everett
context.text: We would think there are some limitations even on how far the State can go in rejecting the principle of compactness.

context.speaker: Robinson O. Everett
context.text: --I think it may be a situation where you look at a number of factors and decide whether the paramount purpose was to achieve a particular result.

context.speaker: Robinson O. Everett
context.text: If you--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Everett--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: --Mr. Everett, I thought part of your answer to Justice Souter's question was that race could be taken into consideration if race had previously been taken into consideration in an adverse way--

context.speaker: Robinson O. Everett
context.text: --That's--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: --that you could right that wrong.

context.speaker: H. Jefferson Powell
context.text: We'd have a very different case.

context.speaker: H. Jefferson Powell
context.text: The answer would depend on the application of section 2.

context.speaker: H. Jefferson Powell
context.text: In appropriate circumstances, section 2, in order to avoid vote dilution as in the Gingles situation, might require majority-minority districting.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: No, but take Justice Kennedy's question just one step further.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Supposing just as a matter of policy, forgetting the Voting Rights Act... assume no Voting Rights Act... could the State constitutionally decide that when... if 20 percent of the population is of a particular race, that it would be good policy to have two districts in which that race represented the majority of the voters in the district?

context.speaker: H. Jefferson Powell
context.text: No, Justice Stevens.

context.speaker: H. Jefferson Powell
context.text: --It would be constitutional.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: --even if there were no Voting Rights Act.

context.speaker: H. Jefferson Powell
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But I thought you answered Justice Kennedy's question to the same effect exactly the opposite.

context.speaker: H. Jefferson Powell
context.text: I'm sorry, Mr. Chief Justice.

context.speaker: H. Jefferson Powell
context.text: I may have misspoken.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: With due respect, Justice, I disagree.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: And the reason I would disagree is because the decisions that are cited by the Government in its brief and some of the decisions that I cite in our brief is that there are situations that... where somebody has a firearm that is located proximally to where drugs are being held, and those people have been convicted of use, people who have been convicted of use who have firearms that are totally inoperable, that do not have firing pins, do not have ammunition, that are located in remote locations.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Those people have also been convicted of use under their definition and the majority of the lower courts'.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: In fact, in Justice White's... in Justice Thomas' dissent in Mewks v. United States, that was their concern that this definition of the word use is... becomes an all-encompassing definition and it means possession and presumes the intent to use.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: So, not only is this important to the case of John Angus Smith, but it is important to countless others who may possess firearms and not have a use.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Moreover, with this definition that the Government encourages here, both in the lower courts and from this Court, it also encourages the lower courts to engage in psycho journeys into the defendants' minds to try and determine their intent, and it requires situation-by-situation, case-by-case analyses--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: With due respect, Justice, I disagree.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: And the reason I would disagree is because the decisions that are cited by the Government in its brief and some of the decisions that I cite in our brief is that there are situations that... where somebody has a firearm that is located proximally to where drugs are being held, and those people have been convicted of use, people who have been convicted of use who have firearms that are totally inoperable, that do not have firing pins, do not have ammunition, that are located in remote locations.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Those people have also been convicted of use under their definition and the majority of the lower courts'.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: In fact, in Justice White's... in Justice Thomas' dissent in Mewks v. United States, that was their concern that this definition of the word use is... becomes an all-encompassing definition and it means possession and presumes the intent to use.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: So, not only is this important to the case of John Angus Smith, but it is important to countless others who may possess firearms and not have a use.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Moreover, with this definition that the Government encourages here, both in the lower courts and from this Court, it also encourages the lower courts to engage in psycho journeys into the defendants' minds to try and determine their intent, and it requires situation-by-situation, case-by-case analyses--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, doesn't the word carrying carry... strike that.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Doesn't the word carrying suggest even more strongly than the word use in this context an offensive or protective purpose?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I mean, carrying is not a broader term than use, which is what your answer to Justice Kennedy seemed to assume.

context.speaker: Gary Kollin
context.text: Well, I think that one of the courts have held that carrying is a very narrow... the lower courts have held that carry is a very narrow definition and use has a very... has lost its active connotation.

context.speaker: Gary Kollin
context.text: But I think carry means to possess in transit or possess and transport.

context.speaker: Kenneth L. Gillis
context.text: In its forcible detainer and entry act, an eviction that goes ahead without a proper court order can be the subject of a damage action.

context.speaker: Kenneth L. Gillis
context.text: That remedy was always available, as was pointed out earlier.

context.speaker: Kenneth L. Gillis
context.text: If there are no other questions we would ask this honorable Court to affirm the conviction.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: In Texas against Brown Justice Stevens said that the Fourth Amendment protects two interests of the citizen, the interest in retaining possession of property and the interest in maintaining personal privacy.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: You disagree with that?

context.speaker: Kenneth L. Gillis
context.text: I think we do.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court in No. 91-6516, Soldal versus Cook County Illinois will be announced by Justice White.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: For the reasons stated in an opinion for unanimous Court which is on file with the Clerk and the judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit in this case is reversed and the case is remanded for further proceedings.

context.speaker: Brian Stuart Koukoutchos
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: Brian Stuart Koukoutchos
context.text: That is because the Corps of Engineers controls the public access to the water projects.

context.speaker: Brian Stuart Koukoutchos
context.text: The... with reference to the land in this case, that was reserved expressly... the grazing rights on the land were reserved expressly to the tribe, and there was a Comptroller General opinion I believe in 1977 which said that the tribe has exclusive authority to permit grazing on this land without regard to whether or not it originally had been taken from fee owner or whether or not taken in trust from the tribe.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Can I take you back to Justice Scalia's question, and as I understand his question, it doesn't depend, it doesn't implicate any of these reservations of rights that you have been describing here.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: It implicates simply the general provisions for the governance of lands taken in fee by the Corps or by the United States for Corps of Engineers projects, and it guarantees public access.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And his question is... for fishing.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: We will resume then.

context.speaker: James D. Vail
context.text: Thank you.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Vail, we'll resume where we left off.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: You were pondering the answer to Justice Stevens' question, I think.

context.speaker: James D. Vail
context.text: Thank you, Your Honor.

context.speaker: James D. Vail
context.text: Mr. Justice, I understand the question--

context.speaker: James D. Vail
context.text: We did, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: And did you raise the jury instruction issue in the court of appeals?

context.speaker: James D. Vail
context.text: We did, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Was the jury instructed in line with Justice Stevens' questions, that the defendant could rebut the inference, or was there an instruction on that point at all?

context.speaker: James D. Vail
context.text: There was not, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Did you ask for one?

context.speaker: Gary L. Gardner
context.text: --It's legitimate... he doesn't sandbag the court and say if you're going to find this, this is the real reason.

context.speaker: Gary L. Gardner
context.text: It's legitimate if that third reason comes out in the plaintiff's case, as it did in this case.

context.speaker: Gary L. Gardner
context.text: The plaintiff knows it's there.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Yes, but if that's the case, then why don't we go right back to the point that I guess Justice Scalia made and say the real error in this case is that there was never a prima facie case made?

context.speaker: Gary L. Gardner
context.text: It can be looked at that way.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Let's not monkey with the standards for raising defenses if, in fact, the very first stage, even that is the predicate for shifting to the... or raising the burden of going forward is not satisfied.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Well--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: --Just make it clear to me, what precisely are you asking the Court to do?

context.speaker: William Mallory Kent
context.text: Well, precisely, I'm asking the Court to vacate Mr. Stinson's sentence, to remand it for resentencing with instructions that this commentary is clarifying commentary and is to be applied to his... determination of his sentence.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Well, that's what Justice White was suggesting too, I think.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Well--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: --I mean it's not--

context.speaker: John Wilson Reed
context.text: It may be that there are such obvious cases.

context.speaker: John Wilson Reed
context.text: They will be very few, I would think, and even when you see cases where things are on videotape, nevertheless people and juries and lawyers advocating cases to juries--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: --But Mr. Reed, in most States... I don't know if it's true in Louisiana or not... the defendant simply enters a plea of not guilty.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: You don't deny the allegations, as I understand it, in the indictment, and so the situation which you advert to in answer to Justice O'Connor's question where the defendant relies only on affirmative defense would be a purely fictional one.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I mean, a defendant can always say he's just putting the Government to its proof, can't he?

context.speaker: John Wilson Reed
context.text: --If the defendant is, indeed, Your Honor, putting the Government to its proof on the elements of the offense and requiring it to prove them beyond a reasonable doubt, then we would suggest that you cannot apply harmless error in the ordinary way, but must instead look to see whether he was relying on it and if he was then it cannot be harmless.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But of course, that kind of argument was made against a whole notion of harmless error when it was first introduced, but courts can't second-guess juries.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We never know what a jury would have done had this evidence been brought before it, even though rational people would have said it didn't make much difference, but that line of argument was rejected for the great majority of harmless error applications saying that the principle of harmless error was applicable.

context.speaker: John Wilson Reed
context.text: And in every case, Your Honor, it was rejected, and in every case harmless error analysis was conducted in light of and because there was before the court a jury finding of something beyond a reasonable doubt to that jury's certainty, and while I don't dispute that there may be some subjectivity that might go into the harmless error process of adding and subtracting to that, there is the integrity of a jury finding beyond a reasonable doubt.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, suppose that we flesh out a little bit Justice O'Connor's hypothesis and say that there were four eyewitnesses, each to a murder with which the defendant is charged.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Each of them is grilled extensively by defense counsel, and it only firms up the witness' account... those things do happen, as you know.

context.speaker: John Wilson Reed
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: It gives no discount for present value of money, which is routine in, say, wage earner cases.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And I think this is a highly exaggerated figure that you're asking us to rely upon.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: --Justice Kennedy, let me address those points.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Plus the fact, as Justice O'Connor put it, it was never pointed out to the jury or the Supreme Court anyway.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: Justice Kennedy, with respect to the discount rate, we were projecting figures using the $3 that was the price in 1985.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: TXO's own experts in defense exhibit 14 indicated that they expected the price of gas, over the 20-year life of the wells, to go up by a factor of 4 or 5.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court of No. 91-1229, United States against McDermott will be announced by Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The case is here on writ of certiorari to the Tenth Circuit.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The dispute involves competing priorities of a federal tax lien and a private creditor's judgment lien.

United States By and Through Internal Re.speaker: Justice Scalia

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It could have been a tie, it also, was a lien in covering after acquired property and it also attached and became perfected when the McDermotts acquired the property.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: We think , however, that under the language and Section 6323(a), the filing of the notice renders the federal tax lien extant for first in time purposes regardless of whether it has yet attached to identifiable property.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That reading is confirmed by the Provision, two subsections later and Section 6323(c)(1) which, for reasons too tedious to describe, reflects the assumption at the tax lien once filed will prevail regardless it when it attaches.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Justice Thomas has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justice Stevens and Justice O'Connor join.

context.text: We think , however, that under the language and Section 6323(a), the filing of the notice renders the federal tax lien extant for first in time purposes regardless of whether it has yet attached to identifiable property.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That reading is confirmed by the Provision, two subsections later and Section 6323(c)(1) which, for reasons too tedious to describe, reflects the assumption at the tax lien once filed will prevail regardless it when it attaches.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Justice Thomas has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justice Stevens and Justice O'Connor join.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: We're just arguing about what statute of limitations applies.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That's... that's the issue in this case, isn't it?

context.speaker: Robert D. Milam
context.text: --Well if--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: So even if your response to Justice Stevens were yes, the United States would... could proceed in Federal Court against the... against the lawyer, you... you still might be--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --Even if... even if the statute of limitation is run, is my question.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Even if the State statute's run.

context.speaker: William C. Bryson
context.text: --No, we're not claiming that--
--Okay.

context.speaker: William C. Bryson
context.text: --That's right.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: May I just ask you to carry your response to Justice Souter one step further?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Why is this different from the felony murder case, then?

context.speaker: William C. Bryson
context.text: Oh, I think it's very different, because in felony murder, Your Honor, you have an aggravated form of a lesser offense in which the aggravating statute incorporates by specific reference all the elements of the lesser--

context.speaker: William C. Bryson
context.text: --Typically read.

context.speaker: William C. Bryson
context.text: They do not provide... they do not incorporate the specific elements of the underlying felonies, or the underlying crimes.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: --No, but when you have court orders that do, why don't they meet the Blockburger standard everybody talks about here?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: It seems to me Blockburger is... the same suggestion I guess Justice Souter was making.

context.speaker: William C. Bryson
context.text: Well, it is simply the difference, Your Honor, between an offense and conduct that may constitute an offense as we see it.

context.speaker: William C. Bryson
context.text: In other words, the conduct in the case of contempt is the violation of the particular court order that's been entered in--

United States v. Edge Broadcasting Compa.speaker: Justice Stevens
United States v. Edge Broadcasting Compa.case_name: United States v. Edge Broadcasting Company
United States v. Edge Broadcasting Compa.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 21, 1993

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I see.

context.speaker: Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
context.text: But turning to the First Amendment part of it, we think that the Central Hudson test, as I said, is sufficiently flexible that it allows this sort of approach that we have here to be undertaken.

context.speaker: Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
context.text: The essential objection raised--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Larkin, may I just pursue Justice Kennedy's point one step further to get it sharp?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: It seems to me the question should be whether the State of North Carolina, to follow up on Justice Scalia's notion, could prohibit gambling advertising of the lotteries in Virginia in its own newspapers in the state.

context.speaker: Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
context.text: --I think if it's illegal in North Carolina--

United States v. Edge Broadcasting Compa.speaker: Justice Stevens
United States v. Edge Broadcasting Compa.case_name: United States v. Edge Broadcasting Company
United States v. Edge Broadcasting Compa.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 21, 1993

context.speaker: Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
context.text: But turning to the First Amendment part of it, we think that the Central Hudson test, as I said, is sufficiently flexible that it allows this sort of approach that we have here to be undertaken.

context.speaker: Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
context.text: The essential objection raised--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Larkin, may I just pursue Justice Kennedy's point one step further to get it sharp?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: It seems to me the question should be whether the State of North Carolina, to follow up on Justice Scalia's notion, could prohibit gambling advertising of the lotteries in Virginia in its own newspapers in the state.

context.speaker: Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
context.text: --I think if it's illegal in North Carolina--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: It's illegal in North Carolina, but it's not illegal for the citizens, as I understand you, to go across the border and buy the tickets.

United States v. Edge Broadcasting Compa.speaker: Justice Souter
United States v. Edge Broadcasting Compa.case_name: United States v. Edge Broadcasting Company
United States v. Edge Broadcasting Compa.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 21, 1993

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, that's true, but the fourth prong simply requires that the regulation not be more extensive.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: This isn't more extensive, is it?

context.speaker: Conrad Moss Shumadine
context.text: I think it is to the extent that it picks up stations like Edge where it has no effect or it doesn't accomplish any governmental purpose.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, I think this gets back to Justice White's colloquy.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Whether there might be ways in which the Government could accomplish that purpose more effectively is a different question.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: It accomplishes something.

United States v. Edge Broadcasting Compa.speaker: Justice White
United States v. Edge Broadcasting Compa.case_name: United States v. Edge Broadcasting Company
United States v. Edge Broadcasting Compa.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 21, 1993

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Yes, but it's only marginal because you're just talking about Edge, and if you talk about all the stations in North Carolina that are not permitted to carry these ads, why surely there's quite a direct service to the Government interest in protecting the interests of North Carolina.

context.speaker: Conrad Moss Shumadine
context.text: Your Honor, we have not challenged the application of the statute as it applies in other areas where you do not have the particular type of overlap that we are talking about here.

context.speaker: Conrad Moss Shumadine
context.text: We limited our challenge to an as-applied as opposed to a facial challenge.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well, that gets you back to Justice O'Connor's earlier question.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Is that the way you approach commercial speech cases?

context.speaker: Conrad Moss Shumadine
context.text: I believe it is, Your Honor, and it's certainly the way that this Court has always approached constitutional questions.

United States v. Edge Broadcasting Compa.speaker: Justice Souter
United States v. Edge Broadcasting Compa.case_name: United States v. Edge Broadcasting Company
United States v. Edge Broadcasting Compa.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 21, 1993

context.speaker: Conrad Moss Shumadine
context.text: --I did make that submission, and the only reason I did not endorse that example is that I think you would have to look at all of the facts in a record to see whether it was effective.

context.speaker: Conrad Moss Shumadine
context.text: If it was totally ineffective, if you said everyone can have billboards except one person, and if you were going to have 10,000 billboards anyway and you were banning 20 additional ones, then I think there would be a real problem.

context.speaker: Conrad Moss Shumadine
context.text: I think it's very important in an as-applied challenge, and we tried very carefully to say this, to stick to the record as made.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Mr. Shumadine, it seems to me although you emphasize in answering Justice Kennedy's question the particularity of the exception that you're arguing for, at least in the context of FCC licensing if we accepted your argument it would be a very broad exception because you in effect would be saying that only, that this particular regulation would be enforceable only with respect to broadcasters over a geographical area which do not receive, as it were, the forbidden broadcasts from outside and which do not in turn broadcast to a substantial audience outside the area in which the activity is forbidden.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: So that I suppose on your theory there might be some kind of enclave in the center of large states in which the regulation would be enforceable, but I'm not sure that it would be enforceable anywhere else.

context.speaker: Conrad Moss Shumadine
context.text: That is not our submission, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Joseph R. Conte
context.text: He's sitting there waiting for a court to sentence him, and the pressures that bear on a person in that position have to be greater presentencing than postsentencing.

context.speaker: Joseph R. Conte
context.text: Although my position is that his Edwards right should apply postsentencing, certainly we would still have a bright line if the Court said that after he has been sentenced, then the Edwards rule doesn't apply.

context.speaker: Joseph R. Conte
context.text: But my position still would be that since it only applies to those activities that occurred prior to the request for his attorney, that truly the need... extending it past the time of sentencing just lowers the likelihood that they're going to come to him and question him about a case that occurred in that time frame prior to it.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Do you know the answer to Justice Scalia's question about why the statute, 18 U.S. Code 3501, does not bear on this question?

context.speaker: Joseph R. Conte
context.text: No, I don't.

context.speaker: Joseph R. Conte
context.text: 3501, though, is a... anytime a statement is made, it seems as though that there is always a hearing to find out whether it was voluntary, whether it met... meets all the parameters that have been dictated by the United States Code and by this Court.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the court in two cases will be announced by Justice O'Connor.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: The first is United States versus Olano.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: This case comes to the Court on writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: The respondents have made no specific showing of prejudice and we will not presume prejudice here because the District Court specifically instructed the alternate jurors not to participate.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Thus, the Court of Appeals lack the authority to correct the error.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals accordingly is reversed in the case is remanded.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Justice Kennedy has filed a concurring opinion; Justice Stevens has filed a dissenting opinion joined by Justices White and Blackmun.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor

context.speaker: William C. Bryson
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: --Why were you getting into the question of the authority of the driver of the car to consent to the opening of the trunk?

context.speaker: William C. Bryson
context.text: Well, only because the--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: He can't get a whole chain of title to the car when he's--

context.speaker: William C. Bryson

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Supposing the house doesn't sell for the full amount of the down payment plus the purchase money mortgage.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Who gets priority?

context.speaker: Amy L. Wax
context.text: I believe that the answer is that each entity, the Government to the extent they have an interest, the mortgage... the mortgagee to the extent they do, take the loss proportionately on that decline in the equity of the house.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Ms. Wax, could I come back to Justice O'Connor's hypothetical?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It seems to me you made the answer easy by assuming that the woman, when she sold the... when she mortgaged the house, put the money into the house or put the money in the bank.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: And, therefore, you say, we'd go after the money, and the bank would still have its mortgage in the real estate.

context.text: The opinion of the Court in No. 91-781, United States versus A Parcel of Land will be announced by Justice Stevens.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: In 1978, the Congress amended the Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act to provide for the forfeiture of proceeds, traceable to money or other things of value earned from drug trafficking.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: This case raises questions concerning the innocent owner in defense that is included in that amendment.

United States v. Parcel of Rumson, N. J..speaker: Justice Stevens
United States v. Parcel of Rumson, N. J..case_name: United States v. Parcel of Rumson, N. J., Land
United States v. Parcel of Rumson, N. J..title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - FEBRUARY 24, 1993

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The government does however argued that it becomes the owner of drug proceeds as soon as an illegal transaction takes place, and that respondent's home was therefore purchased with the government property.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: We reject that argument because both the common law and the statutory relation back doctrine, on which the government relies, only provide for a retroactive vesting of title after the government has obtained the forfeiture judgment.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Until that time, the government is not the owner of the property, and the person such as respondent, who does own the property until then, may involve to any defense otherwise available to her.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
