context.speaker: Thomas G. Hungar
context.text: The agencies are charged with authority to construe the Debt Collection Act, and in the exercise of that congressionally delegated authority the agencies have determined the scope of the Debt Collection Act, and in their view the Debt Collection Act does not abrogate the common law.

context.speaker: Thomas G. Hungar
context.text: That's the end of the agencies, of the scope of the agencies' deference.

context.speaker: Thomas G. Hungar
context.text: But that determination, which is the determination at issue in this case, is entitled to deference.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: May I go back again to the text of the regulation that Justice Souter called your attention to, that they are authorized to assess interest on debts not subject to 3717 to the extent authorized under the common law.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I would have read that to mean to the extent that agencies are authorized under the common law.

context.speaker: Thomas G. Hungar
context.text: Well, any ambiguity that there may be in the regulation is quite clearly resolved by the explanatory statement in the notice of rule making that accompanied the promulgation of that regulation in 1984, which we have discussed that in our opening brief.

context.speaker: Armistead W. Gilliam, Jr.
context.text: Where blacks are gerrymandered or anybody is gerrymandered, the entire purpose of the gerrymander is to move a group out of a district where they're expressing a voting preference, where they're engaged in some sort of influence.

context.speaker: Armistead W. Gilliam, Jr.
context.text: If they didn't have influence, there wouldn't be a reason to gerrymander them, and that is what occurred in this case.

context.speaker: Armistead W. Gilliam, Jr.
context.text: I want to--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Mr. Gilliam, in the response that you gave to, I guess it was, Justice Stevens' question where you... your object is to pack Democrats, but an easy way to do it is that since you believe that the... that blacks are largely voting Democratic, you've packed blacks as a means of packing Democrats, you said that would be bad.

context.speaker: Armistead W. Gilliam, Jr.
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That would only be bad I think you would say if you can establish block voting.

context.speaker: Armistead W. Gilliam, Jr.
context.text: Well, I think packing is dilutive.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Well, it's evidence of dilution in other districts.

context.speaker: Armistead W. Gilliam, Jr.
context.text: It's evidence of dilution, and it is dilution under my theory, Your Honor, if I may.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Well, then you seem to be giving a different answer than you gave to Justice Souter.

context.speaker: Armistead W. Gilliam, Jr.
context.text: Well, in that case, I'm mistaken.

context.speaker: Armistead W. Gilliam, Jr.
context.text: Somehow or other I'm confused.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the court in No. 91-1618 Voinovich versus Quilter would be announced by Justice O'Connor.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: This case is on appeal from a three-judge District Court for the Northern District of Ohio.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: In 1991, the Ohio State Apportionment Board reapportioned the electoral districts for the state legislature there in accordance with Ohio State Constitution's requirement that reapportion be conducted every 10 years.

context.speaker: James E. Doyle
context.text: They looked at the model ADL statute for example and declared what these kinds of, what these kinds of laws mean in First Amendment terms.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: That's on page A8 and A9 of the Appendix.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The discussion of the model statute is right after the comment that Justice Scalia has in mind, I think, because the state court does say without doubt the hate crime statute punishes bigoted thought.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And the state asserts the statute punishes only conduct.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: We disagree.

context.speaker: James E. Doyle
context.text: And I think it would be very difficult to articulate a legitimate state interest in choosing one side of the debate.

context.speaker: James E. Doyle
context.text: The better analogy to the Wisconsin--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But, excuse me, I thought we were presenting from that whether the objectives are good or bad, but you say the objectives have to be a legitimate state interest?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: See, I thought from your initial answer to Justice Souter that you would have said, or I gathered from Justice Souter's question that it's a different case if you say you get an enhanced penalty for assault if the reason for your assault is that the person you assault favors the Vietnam war.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You would say that's bad too, wouldn't you?

context.speaker: James E. Doyle
context.text: --I would say that that would, it's far removed from the Wisconsin example, but I think that it would present to the court a legitimate concern that the Government is attempting to suppress ideas of the Government.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But is there any evidence that disabled people have been beaten up because they are disabled?

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: --I don't know that there is any evidence in this record.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: There is clearly evidence in Federal policy reflected in the anti-discrimination laws.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Yes, but I thought your argument was that, in response to Justice Kennedy's question, if there are a rash of church burnings, sure, the state, the Federal Government can come in and legislate about that.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But here we're talking about a situation where there hasn't been a rash of anything so far as anybody knows, so far as attacks on the disabled because they are disabled.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: It may be evidenced in a particular case that there is no real-life problem that the state is attempting to regulate, that the state has some other goal in mind.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: --It is a factor to be considered in the totality of the circumstances, yes.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: So if we adopted your rule, we would be inquiring into whether or not the Miranda warning had been given and its effect in any event in all those voluntariness cases.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Well, it would be one of the factors to be considered.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: This goes to Justice Souter's question.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: We think there's a very significant gain from excluding Miranda from habeas corpus.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: This Court knows from its own Miranda jurisprudence that cases under Miranda can present very difficult technical issues... the content of the warnings, when they're triggered, how they apply to subsequent arrests.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: --De novo review.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: So that's a considerable undertaking, isn't it?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Well, in particular cases it may be, but I suppose that, when you mentioned, Justice Souter, the practical effect, I think what the assumption is that a prisoner is going to sort of raise a claim even if it's frivolous, and--

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well, it's a considerably tougher operation than applying the Miranda rules, I would think.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: --Well, but it's an operation that the courts have to undertake now in any event.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court in No. 91-1030, Withrow against Williams will be announced by Justice Souter.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: This case comes to us on writ of certiorari in the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The respondent, Williams, brought this habeas actions challenging the legality of the state convictions for murder and other offenses.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: In an opinion filed with the Clerk of the Court today we affirm and hold at Stone's restriction on the exercise of federal habeas jurisdiction does not extend to Miranda claims.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The equitable considerations that formed the basis for a decision in Stone do not obtain here.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Most importantly, eliminating review of Miranda claims would not significantly benefit the Federal Courts in their exercise of habeas jurisdiction or advanced the cause of federalism in any substantial way.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Justice O'Connor has filed an opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part, which the Chief Justice joins; Justice Scalia has filed an opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part which Justice Thomas joins.

Zobrest v. Catalina Foothills School Dis.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 24, 1993

context.speaker: John C. Richardson
context.text: So--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I'm sorry.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: May I ask you to clarify one thing for me?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: In your response to Justice White, you spoke about the need to make a judgment statewide about the appropriateness of your providing this kind of service in a private school and so on.

context.speaker: John C. Richardson
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Aren't you addressing in that answer a different regulation from the one that I mentioned?
